awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Communication-network-free, Autonomous, Renewable Electric Power Systems (CARE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The vision for the proposed Engineering Research Center for Communication-network-free,
Autonomous, Renewable Electric Power Systems (CARE) is to develop the foundational
research in multiple technical areas, versatile workforce, inclusive culture, and innovative ecosystems necessary to achieve autonomous operation of future electric power systems with high penetration of renewable and distributed energy resources without relying on communication networks.  The ERC will focus on making renewable and distributed energy resources behave like conventional synchronous machines, bringing backwards compatibility to power systems. This will ensure continuation of the mechanism of synchronous machines, which has contributed to growth and stable operation of power systems for over 100 years. This ERC will also promote convergent collaborative research and education among engineering systems, mathematical, social, and psychosocial sciences, and economics, which will benefit the societies individually and collectively. The planning grant will conduct three workshops to refine the goals of the proposed ERC, while building the team and engaging a wide range of stakeholders to achieve these goals. 

The proposed concept of ERC is motivated by the need to harmonize future power systems with high penetration of renewable and distributed energy resources, achieve autonomous operation of power systems without relying on expensive and complex communication networks, and avoid potential malicious cyber-attacks that could be launched by anybody, at any time, from anywhere. A divergent
bottom-up approach will be taken to brainstorm ideas and then a convergent top-down approach will be
taken to develop the strategic plans for the four foundational components of the ERC in three themed one-day workshops. The outcomes of the themed workshops will directly contribute to the preparation of the
full CARE ERC proposal. This planning grant will help the team to further advance the seed idea of the proposed CARE ERC in terms of its four foundational components: Research, Innovation Ecosystem, Engineering Workforce Development, and Diversity and Culture of Inclusion, into a solid ERC proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Electrification is the greatest engineering achievement of the 20th century and power systems are arguably the most important infrastructure that underpins social life and economic growth. Power systems have been dominated by centralized large generation facilities that burn fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and gas. While fossil fuels have greatly contributed to the world's civilization, two consequences have emerged: one is that fossil fuels are not sustainable and the other is that the combustion of fossil fuels emits green-house gases, which is a major cause for climate change - one of today's most pressing global challenges. The large-scale adoption of renewable distributed energy resources (DER) has been widely accepted as a promising means to tackle these two challenges. However, this brings unprecedented challenges to grid stability, reliability, security, and resiliency. Adding information and communication technology (ICT) systems into power systems, hence the birth of smart grids, has emerged as a potential solution to make power systems more efficient, more resilient to threats, and friendlier to the environment. However, this leads to serious reliability and security concerns. The computer outage of Aerodata happened on April 1, 2019, which affected all major US airlines with 3000+ flight cancellations and delays, sent a clear warning to the power industry. Similar system-wide outages could easily happen to power systems if their operation relies on ICT systems. Moreover, when the number of players reaches a certain level, how to manage the ICT systems is itself a challenge. What is even worse is that adding ICT systems to power systems opens the door for cyber-attacks by anybody, at any time, from anywhere. This trend has to be stopped, the sooner the better.
        The team proposed to establish an Engineering Research Center for Cybersecure, Autonomous, Renewable Electric Power Systems (CARE)  to develop convergent foundational research, versatile workforce, inclusive culture, and innovative ecosystems to achieve and underpin the autonomous operation of future electric power systems with high penetration of renewable and distributed energy resources without relying on communication networks, making power systems worldwide stable, reliable, sustainable, autonomous, secure, and resilient. 
        This planning grant helped the team further advance the seed idea of the proposed CARE ERC in terms of its four foundational components: Research, Innovation Ecosystem, Engineering Workforce Development, and Diversity and Culture of Inclusion, into a solid ERC preliminary proposal. A divergent bottom-up approach was taken to brainstorm ideas and then a convergent top-down approach was taken to develop the strategic plans for the four foundational components of the ERC. The team organized a Workshop on Power Electronics-enabled Operation of Power Systems at the lead institution (Illinois Institute of Technology) in Chicago on October 31 - November 1, 2019 with the support of the NSF Award #1933207, which attracted over 130 registrations. Through this workshop and the project, the team networked with the wider community in power electronics, power systems and control systems theory,  identified additional project partners, and advanced the ideas for the ERC proposal. The team prepared and submitted a Preliminary Proposal entited "NSF Engineering Research Center for Cybersecure, Autonomous, Renewable Electric Power Systems (CARE)" with a well-crafted vision to NSF. "The panel reviewing this proposal was enthusiastic of the overall value of this ERC concept" and recommended "Invite if Possible."
